element_texts.text: Completed

WILLIAM H. BALDWIN
15 CLARK STREET
Main 4781 J
Brooklyn, April 6. 
(1926)
My dear Mrs. Carpenter:
I have just sent you a night letter saying that Mr. Culin will lend the Arts Club a collection of African art. His consent is subject to the approval of the trustees of the Brooklyn Museum who meet tomorrow, but I gathered that there will be no trouble there. 
Mr. Culin showed me his exhibit in the Museum & it is well worth a visit. As a Brooklynite, I am ashamed that I had not seen it before. Of course, he cannot send out anything as large as this main collection, but I believe he will lend enough to form a fairly representative exhibit.
The main part will be specimens of weaving & designing in textiles. In addition there will be some 8 or 10 masks. All these are mounted for easy hanging on the walls. Then there will be enough figures (wood & possibly some of ivory) to show the skill in carving. These will need a glass case for

Caption-Abstract: Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.

element_texts.text: Completed

2. 
WILLIAM H. BALDWIN
15 CLARK STREET
Main 4781 J
display. You can undoubtedly borrow such a case from one of the local museums or from a store. I will send you the necessary dimensions for the case later. It may be that when he starts to pack the things up he will wax enthusiastic & put in some other specimens.
Can you send me some details as to where you plan to show the collection--address, approximate wall space, etc. A photograph of the interior would be most helpful if one is available. It would guide him in selecting the number & type of specimens. 
note in pencil: May 1st Fisk singers
I told Mr. Culin that it was  my understanding that the Fisk Singers would open the exhibit with a concert & that his collection would then remain on view for several days. He tells me that several New York firms have developed textile, dress & even hat designs from some of his African specimens, & probably there will be a similar interest in Chicago.

element_texts.text: Completed

3.
WILLIAM H. BALDWIN
15 CLARK STREET
Main 4781 J
Mr. Culin can have his collection packed & ready for shipment in about ten days & then it should go forward to you by express. The costs will be express & insurance (which he says are fairly nominal) & the expense of unpacking & repacking in Chicago. He assumes that a responsible person will handle the specimens & suggests that Dr. Laufer of the Field Museum might be willing to cooperate. 
I found Mr. Culin a delightful old gentleman & I am sure that he has more of the spirit of Brotherly Love than our Philadelphia friend. At the same time he is going to be put to considerable trouble in assembling & packing the exhibit & I know that a letter expressing your appreciation & assuring him that his beloved specimens will be carefully handled, will please him. His full name is on the title page of the catalogue which I left at your home.
Ii am sending from the office tomorrow a copy of a letter to Dr. Barnes.

element_texts.text: Completed

4. 
WILLIAM H. BALDWIN
15 CLARK STREET
Main 4781 J
He is a most extraordinary creature & I wouldn't be too exercized by the recent outburst. For certain reasons of state, I shall have to try to mollify him (with my tongue in my cheek); but you are left perfectly free to be irritated by as uniquely bad manners as I have seen in some time. When I telegraphed Mr. Varney last Friday I had had only a distorted version of your telegram to Dr. Barnes.
I trust that, the Barnes experiment having proved a colossal failure, the pendulum will swing & the Arts Club will have a most interesting & successful experience with the Fisk Singers & Mr. Culin.
With appreciation of your continued interest & with regards to Mr. Carpenter,
I am
Cordially yours,
William H. Baldwin

element_texts.text: Completed

MURRAY HILL 6542
THE FISK JUBILEE SINGERS
(FROM FISK UNIVERSITY, NASHVILLE TENNESSEE)
WALTER K. VARNEY, MANAGER
501 FIFTH AVENUE
NEW YORK 
APRIL 7, (1926)
Dear Mr. Carpenter:
A succession of things has kept me out of this office until after  my secretary had left & I cannot put my hands on your recent letter. But what you want most is the copy of my letter to Barnes; this I am enclosing, & I shall acknowledge your letter later. 
I trust Mrs. Carpenter has received my telegram & the letter I wrote her from home last evening. 
Hastily,
W.H. Baldwin

Hotel Muehlebach
Whitmore Hotel Co.
Lessee
BALTIMORE AVENUE
AND TWELFTH STREET
Kansas City, Mo.
Nov? 2nd 1926.
Miss Alice Roullier
Albert Roullier Art Galleries
410 South Michigan Boulevard
Chicago
Dear Miss Roullier:-
I feel I must write and thank you for your kindness to me while in Chicago and to say how much we appreciate your offer in allowing us to Exhibit at the Arts Club of Chicago
Perhaps I shall have the pleasure in seeing you in England next Summer, when, I hope, you will find time to visit our painting at Stonebridge? Thanking you again. I am, yours sincerely
Gilbert C. Johnston

element_texts.text: Completed

EACH ROOM WITH PRIVATE BATH       BELL PHONE  DELMAR 7100
FAIRMONT HOTEL
Maryland at Euclid
Saint Louis
Dec. 16th/26
My dear Ms. Leitner.
Your answering telegram was received this afternoon, for which many thanks. We have been anxious about the "wind-up" as so much depends upon it.
We cannot understand why Ms. Hume should relinquish the beautiful table she so much desired--Did she wire canceling her order for it?
We will appreciate a letter stating how it came about as we are amazed at this turn of affairs--The Lowensteins wrote that they were returning the lovely old Queen Anne Secretaire, reluctantly, because it was too large for their space in the living-room. That deducts $1500.00 from our totals, and adding Ms. Hume's table, makes 1800.00--a blow! I presume the large old Sheffield tray in library closet was delivered with the marquetry desk to Ms. Dole--Mr. Whitney asks that you will please send him the receipt Mr. Miller got from the Safety Deposit Co- for the two boxes of M. Wallace Winter's silver left with them.

element_texts.text: Completed

This is very necessary as, if there should be a robbery there, we could not otherwise prove that we hd had the Silver delivered-
Kindly send whatever bills--prepaid expressive by The Arts Club and older matters--to Mr. Whitney to be O.K'd for payment by Miss Craig. We are not surprised that Ms. Bauer did not take the urn as she does not seem to think long enough about anything to know whether she wants a thing or not-
We will be glad to have it here as there are many inquiries for urns-
Hoping that you and Loretta will have a happy Christmas and with greetings and good wishes to Miss Jarvis, and awaiting your letter with enclosures, I ham most sincerely yours
Julia B. Whitney--
P.S. Please destroy this letter at once-

element_texts.text: Completed

1
Tapestry is one of the oldest of the arts, one of the oldest because in basic technique it is one of the simplest and most obvious, for in the essentials of its weaving it differs from the kind of weaving that a woman does in darning a stocking only in that in tapestry the wefts, the second set of threads woven in at right angles to the fist set of parallel bare strings are pressed together so that where the fabric is finished those strings that are the skeleton of the materials, the warps, are completely covered. Because tapestry is thus made with a basic and primitive kind of weaving, it has been invented and developed independently in many different centers of civilisation in different periods. 
The oldest pieces of tapestry in existence are fragments, made of linen from Egyptian graves, the earliest dating from about 3500 B.C. But the art must have been old already at that date for these bits? are certainly the product of an

Caption-Abstract: Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.
Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.
Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.

element_texts.text: Completed

-2-
accomplished and experienced skill. It is not, however, until after the dawn of the Christian era that we find this technique developed to its highest application, the rendition of pictorial designs. The pre-Christian fragments left to us show only conventional patterns but as early as the second century unclear we find pictures, notably portraits, accurately and beautifully woven.-
There follows the first great period of high artistic achievement in tapestry, centered in Egypt and lasting five or six hundred years, perhaps longer from the production of these Egyptian looms, unclear by Copts, the Christians of Egypt descended from the original Egyptian race, hundreds of fragments have come to us. But only a dozen or so show the art in its central and most important function, the reproduction of pictorial models--
It was from Egypt that the art was carried into Europe, carried probably by Copt monks who

Caption-Abstract: Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.
Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.

element_texts.text: Completed

-3-
went into Germany and France and Flanders & established branches of their orders. The earliest examples left to us of this transplanted industry are products of monasteries in the Valley of the Rhine dating from the eleventh century, remnants of three sets in Halberstadt Cathedral.
In another three hundred years, however, the center of the art had shifted to France and Flanders. In Paris and in Arras and somewhat later, the neighboring city of Tournay great guild of weavers were kept busy producing huge hangings, storied with the life of Christ or of his Virgin Mother, with episodes of the great romances, or from the tradition of history or with scenes from contemporary life--This is the second great period of blooming in the art. From that day to this the production of tapestries in Europe has been uninterrupted. But the art maintained its high level of artistic greatness for only about two

Caption-Abstract: Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.

element_texts.text: Completed

-4-
centuries, the fourteenth and fifteenth.
It is the second half of this second great period in the history of the arts, the tapestries of the fifteenth century, that is shown in the Loan Exhibition of Gothic Tapestries at the Arts Club--Gothic is a bad term. It was applied to the art of late medieval France in the eighteenth century as a term of opprobrium. The Goths were barbarians and to the eighteenth century eye the great cathedrals of France were. Hence today when we appreciate the supreme beauty of that architecture it is absurd to retain the name of scorn. Moreover, even if the word is accepted it is not fittingly applied to these tapestries for they are rather later in date than most of the architecture for which it was originally invented. But unfortunately there is no convenient alternative term so Gothic is probably in the language of art to stay.
Tapestries of the earlier half of this second great period of the art are almost nonexistent. We have left only a half dozen fragments and one

Caption-Abstract: Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.

element_texts.text: Completed

5
great set, the series of the Apocalypse of Augers Cathedral. Even early fifteenth century pieces are rare so that it is the greatest good fortune to have in the Arts Club collection a group of these all fragmentary but all representative. It is impossible to say definitely whether the first two pieces in the collection were woven at Arras or Tourney. The two towns are close together and probably the work was very similar. But beginning with the third piece in the catalogue a definite attribution to Tournay is possible. In the later years of the fifteenth century it again becomes difficult to distinguish the works of Tournay but this time th close competitor is not Arras, for the industry had died out there before 1450, but Andeuarde? It was in Tournay that the Dukes of Burgundy, the most lavish patrons that this art ever knew, ordered almost all of their great sets. At the close of the Gothic period Brussels begins to be ascendent and in the end dominates the industry.

Caption-Abstract: Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.

element_texts.text: Completed

-6-
Tapestry unlike painting, can be both adequate and beautiful even when fragmentary, for the character of tapestry composition in this, its first period, is totally unlike that of painting composition. Whereas a painting is focused at a dominant point which controls and holds subordinate all of the rest of the design, a tapestry, when it fulfills its proper rôle, is patterned with distributed interest, a close sequence of successive unclear no one of which is permitted preeminence. Thus even a bit cut off from the whole can make a coherent and self contained unit.  A fragment like the first piece in the Arts Club Exhibition, the Head of a Lady, or like the fix Soldiers, number six in the catalogue, is beautiful in design as well as drawing and sufficient unto itself as an illustrative pattern.
Unclear and centuries rarely come to a close neatly together. The so-called Gothic style, the character of drawing and design that is preeminently

element_texts.text: Completed

-7-
Flemish and primarily of the fifteenth Century continues on well into the Sixteenth century ad in consequence the Arts Club Exhibition includes, quite properly, pieces designed as late as 1520 or 1525. In the latest of these the new Italian fashion that was influencing everything from clothes to castles all over Europe at the moment, is very evident. A particularly interesting example is a Descent from the Cross (No. 7) adapted unblushingly from an engraving by Marc Antonio Raimondi on the basis, probably, of a drawing by Rafael. But even in this boldest borrowing there is a translation of the Italian conception and mannerisms into an idiom strongly Flemish--
With the full triumph of the Renaissance style tapestry's great moment passed--Later pieces are decorative interesting valuable, but they are not great as the Gothic pieces are great. The preeminence of the Gothic tapestry

-8-
has been generally recognized only for a scant quarter of a century but it is so universally admitted? exulted? now there is a quick demand among collectors and museums for every piece that comes into the market. Most of the great pieces that become thus commercially available came to America but they so soon find a permanent place in either private or public collections and the total number left is comparatively so limited it will in a few years, be impossible every again to assemble as complete a series as is shown at the Arts Club.

DEUTSCHER VERIEN FÜR KUNSTWISSENCHAFT E.V.
Abteilung der deutschen Bildwirkereien      WIEN, den 5. 11. 1927
IX Schwarzspanierstraße 7.
Dear Miss Roullier!
I thank you very much indeed for sending me the interesting catalogue of the Exhibition of Gothic Tapestries
I caugh just a glimpse of it and I am looking forward to reviewing it and will see that the review is printed in one of our art journals. I will let you know where and when the review appears. 
Sincerely yours
Betty Kurth
note in pencil: Keep for Ex. Com.

[[Note in pencil: Dr. Ackerman Please return for our files
Feb. 23/27 returned by Dr. Ackerman]]

MUSÉES ROYAUX DU CINQUANTENAIRE
SECTION 1
Bruxelles le 18 1 1927
Chère Miss Roullier,
Je vous remercie pour votre lettre, ainsi que pour le beau Catalogue de Mme Ackerman que je vrais de recevoir.
Je ferai bine voloutiers un compte-rendu de ce catalogue, mais j'aimerais auparavant lire l'article du " College Art Bulletin." Mme Ackerman on avait écrit vers le mois de juin pour m'annoncer cet article, mais, d'après ce que vous me dites, il n'a pas encore paru. Croyez-vous qu'il paraitra bientôt? De toutes façons, j'attendrai pour publier un compte-rendu du Catalogue de votre si

intéressante exposition, d'avoir reçu votre réponse au sujet de l'article le? question.
Présentez je vous prie, mes amities, à l'occasion, à Mme Ackerman, et croyez moi bien, cordialement votre
Marthe Crick-Kuntziger
P.S. Ayant égaré l'address de Mme Ackerman, je me permets d'addresser pour elle, parce même courrier, unclear Arts Club of Chicago, un petit article sur un retable sculpte où je cite son Catalogue de l'Exposition de San Francisco de 1922. 
M.C.K.

VICTORIA & ALBERT MUSEUM, SOUTH KENSINGTON, S.W.7.
Telephone No. : WESTERN 4815. Telegraphic Address VICALEUM, LONDON.
logo stamp MATIONAL SCHEME FOR DISABLED MEN
MEMORANDUM
Library.
6th February 1928.
The Secretary, The Arts Club,
410 North Michigan Avenue, Chicago. 
Dear Sir,
We should be very glad if you could kindly let us have, for use in this Museum, a copy of "Catalogue of a loan exhibition of Gothic tapestries" by Phyllis Ackermann, issued by you in December 1926. 
Yours faithfully
G.H. Palmer,
Keep of the Library
[[note in pencil: O.K. unclear Miss R 2/17/28]]
